title: 109_s934
content: The Act titled "Reform Health Care Now Act" is introduced. Senate consideration of health care reform legislation is outlined. The "Reform Health Care Now Act" mandates the introduction of bills by key Senate members to increase health care coverage within 30 days of the session. If they fail, the minority party can introduce a bill. The respective committee may introduce a bill that qualifies for expedited procedure. The bill must aim to reform the US healthcare system, provide insurance coverage for Americans, reach 95% coverage within 10 years, and be deficit neutral. The Chair of the Senate Budget Committee determines if the bill meets these criteria. The Chair of the Senate Budget Committee, based on estimates from the Congressional Budget Office, has final approval in the Senate. Bills introduced by the Chairs of the Senate Committees on Finance and Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions are referred to their respective committees. If a committee does not report the bill within 60 days, it is automatically discharged and placed on the legislative calendar. The Senate Majority Leader and Minority Leader bills are placed directly on the Senate Calendar of Business. After a committee report or discharge, any Member can move to proceed to consider a bill with prior notice. The motion to proceed to a qualified bill can be made by a Member, even if previously rejected, with a limit of 3 motions per congressional session. The motion is privileged, nondebatable, not amendable, and not subject to postponement. It cannot be reconsidered or lead to other business. If the motion to proceed is adopted, the chamber shall immediately consider a qualified bill without any other business. The bill remains unfinished business until disposed of, and only relevant amendments may be offered. SEC. 3. HOUSE CONSIDERATION OF HEALTH CARE REFORM LEGISLATION. The House Committees and Leaders must introduce bills within 30 days to increase healthcare coverage in the US. If they fail, the minority party can introduce a bill within the next 30 days. The respective committee has 30 days to introduce a bill that qualifies for expedited procedure, aiming to provide healthcare coverage to 95% of Americans within 10 years and be deficit neutral. The Speaker will determine if the bill meets these criteria based on a Congressional Budget Office estimate. Upon introduction, bills authored by the Chairs of the House Committees on Energy and Commerce and Ways and Means will be referred to their respective committees. If a committee fails to report the bill within 60 days, it will be automatically discharged and placed on the Calendar of the Whole House. Bills introduced by the House Majority Leader and House Minority Leader will also undergo expedited procedures for healthcare coverage expansion. Upon introduction, bills by the Majority Leader and House Minority Leader will be placed directly on the Calendar of the Whole House. A motion to proceed to the consideration of any qualified bill can be made after consultation with the Majority Leader, with notice required before proceeding. A qualified bill can be considered even if a similar motion has been rejected before, with a limit of 3 motions per congressional session. The motion to proceed is privileged, nondebatable, not amendable, and not subject to postponement. It cannot be reconsidered or lead to other business. If adopted, the chamber will immediately consider the qualified bill. The chamber will proceed to consider a qualified bill without delay, in the Committee of the Whole under the 5-minute rule, with the bill open for relevant amendments and the option to limit debate.
